message_1: Evaluate the contour integral $\oint_C \frac{z^3 + 3z}{z^2 + 2z + 1} dz$, where $C$ is the positively oriented circle centered at $1 + i$ of radius 2.
message_2:
First, we need to find the poles of the function inside the contour. The function has a denominator of $z^2 + 2z + 1$, which can be factored as $(z+1)^2$. Thus, the function has a pole of order 2 at $z=-1$. Since the contour is a circle of radius 2 centered at $1+i$, the pole at $z=-1$ is inside the contour.

Now, we will find the residue of the function at the pole $z=-1$. To do this, we will use the formula for the residue of a function with a pole of order 2:

$$\text{Res}(f(z), z_0) = \lim_{z \to z_0} \frac{d}{dz} \left[ (z - z_0)^2 f(z) \right]$$

In our case, $f(z) = \frac{z^3 + 3z}{(z+1)^2}$ and $z_0 = -1$. So, we have:

$$\text{Res}(f(z), -1) = \lim_{z \to -1} \frac{d}{dz} \left[ (z + 1)^2 \frac{z^3 + 3z}{(z+1)^2} \right]$$

$$\text{Res}(f(z), -1) = \lim_{z \to -1} \frac{d}{dz} (z^3 + 3z)$$

Now, we differentiate the function with respect to $z$:

$$\frac{d}{dz} (z^3 + 3z) = 3z^2 + 3$$

Now, we evaluate the limit:

$$\text{Res}(f(z), -1) = 3(-1)^2 + 3 = 3 + 3 = 6$$

Now that we have the residue, we can use the residue theorem to evaluate the contour integral:

$$\oint_C \frac{z^3 + 3z}{z^2 + 2z + 1} dz = 2\pi i \sum \text{Res}(f(z), z_k)$$

In our case, there is only one pole inside the contour, so the sum has only one term:

$$\oint_C \frac{z^3 + 3z}{z^2 + 2z + 1} dz = 2\pi i \cdot 6 = 12\pi i$$
